abstract.p: A Joseph Guse letter on Feb 5 article on Energy Department plans to spur improvements in fuel efficiency of trucks (S)

block.p: A Feb. 5 news article reports Energy Department plans to stimulate improvements in the fuel efficiency of light and heavy trucks. However, unless the auto industry believes that a fuel-efficient fleet is marketable, the $100 million effort could produce nothing more than a couple of eco-Humvees for celebrities. As long as gas remains underpriced, consumers will not pay for efficiency.

A Feb. 5 news article reports Energy Department plans to stimulate improvements in the fuel efficiency of light and heavy trucks. However, unless the auto industry believes that a fuel-efficient fleet is marketable, the $100 million effort could produce nothing more than a couple of eco-Humvees for celebrities. As long as gas remains underpriced, consumers will not pay for efficiency.
What will direct their attention to fuel mileage, make the auto industry a willing leader in efficiency research, and improve economic security? A revenue-neutral fuel tax.

A study by the Alliance to Save Energy shows how cutting taxes on labor and capital while shifting the burden onto energy and pollution would help the environment and the economy. This approach has been successfully enacted in Denmark and other European countries.
A. JOSEPH GUSE New Haven, Feb. 6, 1998
